findings.issue: Missing seismic restraint design requirements. DSA requires seismic design per ASCE 7-22 (as adopted by CBC 2022). The specification references ASCE/SEI 7 without specifying the edition, and does not explicitly address DSA-required seismic certification or OPA documentation for equipment and pipe hanger systems.
findings.existingText: Design seismic-restraint hangers and supports for piping and equipment.
findings.replacementText: Design seismic-restraint hangers and supports for piping and equipment according to ASCE 7-22 as adopted by CBC 2022. Include DSA seismic certification and OPA documentation as required by DSA IR A-6.

findings.issue: Shop Drawings submittal requires sealed and stamped engineering calculations but does not explicitly require DSA certification or OPA pre-approval documentation for seismic restraint systems, which is mandatory for K-12 projects under DSA jurisdiction.
findings.existingText: Shop Drawings:  Signed and sealed by a qualified professional engineer. Show fabrication and installation details and include calculations for the following; include Product Data for components:
findings.replacementText: Shop Drawings:  Signed and sealed by a qualified professional engineer. Show fabrication and installation details and include calculations for the following; include Product Data for components. Include DSA seismic certification and OSHPD pre-approval (OPA) documentation for seismic restraint systems per DSA IR A-6.

findings.issue: Section references 'Section 077200 "Roof Accessories" for curbs' but does not verify this section number exists in the project specifications. CSI 2020 format may use different numbering. This creates coordination risk.
findings.existingText: Curb-Mounted-Type Pipe Stands:  Assemble components or fabricate pipe stand and mount on permanent, stationary roof curb.  See Section 077200 "Roof Accessories" for curbs.
findings.replacementText: Curb-Mounted-Type Pipe Stands:  Assemble components or fabricate pipe stand and mount on permanent, stationary roof curb.  Coordinate with roofing specialty section for curb design and installation.

findings.fileName: 230593 - TESTING, ADJUSTING, AND BALANCING FOR HVAC.docx
findings.issue: References LEED Prerequisite IEQ 1 and EA 2 without confirming whether the project is pursuing LEED certification. For a K-12 project under DSA, LEED submissions may not be applicable. This could result in unnecessary or contradictory submittals.
findings.existingText:
LEED Submittals:

Air-Balance Report for Prerequisite IEQ 1:  Documentation of work performed for ASHRAE 62.1, Section 7.2.2 - "Air Balancing."

TAB Report for Prerequisite EA 2:  Documentation of work performed for ASHRAE/IESNA 90.1, Section 6.7.2.3 - "System Balancing."
findings.replacementText:
[If Project pursues LEED Certification, include the following:]

LEED Submittals:

Air-Balance Report for Prerequisite IEQ 1:  Documentation of work performed for ASHRAE 62.1, Section 7.2.2 - "Air Balancing."

TAB Report for Prerequisite EA 2:  Documentation of work performed for ASHRAE/IESNA 90.1, Section 6.7.2.3 - "System Balancing."

findings.fileName: 230593 - TESTING, ADJUSTING, AND BALANCING FOR HVAC.docx
findings.issue: ASHRAE/IESNA 90.1 is referenced but no edition year is specified. California Title 24 2022 references ASHRAE/IESNA 90.1-2019. The specification should specify the edition to ensure code compliance.
findings.existingText: ASHRAE/IESNA Compliance:  Applicable requirements in ASHRAE/IESNA 90.1, Section 6.7.2.3 - "System Balancing."
findings.replacementText: ASHRAE/IESNA Compliance:  Applicable requirements in ASHRAE/IESNA 90.1-2019, Section 6.7.2.3 - "System Balancing," as adopted by California Title 24 2022.

findings.fileName: 230593 - TESTING, ADJUSTING, AND BALANCING FOR HVAC.docx
findings.section: Part 3, EXECUTION - GENERAL PROCEDURES FOR HYDRONIC SYSTEMS
findings.issue: Paragraph specifies 'Do not set at fully closed position when pump is positive-displacement type unless several terminal valves are kept open' but does not cite a standard or provide technical justification. This could create ambiguity during TAB execution.
findings.existingText: Set differential-pressure control valves at the specified differential pressure.  Do not set at fully closed position when pump is positive-displacement type unless several terminal valves are kept open.
findings.replacementText: Set differential-pressure control valves at the specified differential pressure. For positive-displacement pumps, maintain minimum flow through at least one open terminal valve to prevent pump cavitation and ensure safe operation per ASHRAE 111.

findings.fileName: 230553 - IDENTIFICATION FOR HVAC PIPING AND EQUIPMENT.docx
findings.issue: Section states 'Do not use pipe labels or plastic tapes for bare pipes conveying fluids at temperatures of 125 deg F (52 deg C) or higher.' However, the specification later allows preprinted labels without a clear material specification for high-temperature piping. This creates ambiguity about what materials are acceptable at elevated temperatures.
findings.existingText: Do not use pipe labels or plastic tapes for bare pipes conveying fluids at temperatures of 125 deg F (52 deg C) or higher.
findings.replacementText: Do not use plastic tape labels for bare pipes conveying fluids at temperatures of 125 deg F (52 deg C) or higher. For piping above 125 deg F, use tags or labels constructed of materials rated for the maximum service temperature.

findings.fileName: 230553 - IDENTIFICATION FOR HVAC PIPING AND EQUIPMENT.docx
findings.issue: Specification requires valve tags on 'valves and control devices in piping systems, except check valves; valves within factory-fabricated equipment units; shutoff valves; faucets...' The term 'control devices' is not clearly defined, creating ambiguity about which devices require tags. This could result in incomplete or inconsistent tagging.
findings.existingText: Install tags on valves and control devices in piping systems, except check valves; valves within factory-fabricated equipment units; shutoff valves; faucets; convenience and lawn-watering hose connections; and HVAC terminal devices and similar roughing-in connections of end-use fixtures and units.
findings.replacementText: Install tags on all isolation, balance, and service valves in piping systems, except check valves; valves within factory-fabricated equipment units; shutoff valves; faucets; convenience and lawn-watering hose connections; and HVAC terminal devices and similar roughing-in connections of end-use fixtures and units. Tag all 3-way and 2-way control valves.

findings.issue: ASTM C 795 is referenced for qualification of insulation materials for austenitic stainless steel, but the standard cited is for 'Thermal Insulation for Use in Equipment Operating at Temperatures Between Minus 45 deg C (-50 deg F) and Plus 93 deg C (200 deg F).' This may not be the appropriate standard for all duct insulation temperature ranges. Confirm standard applicability.
findings.existingText: Insulation materials for use on austenitic stainless steel shall be qualified as acceptable according to ASTM C 795.
findings.replacementText: Insulation materials for use on austenitic stainless steel shall be qualified as acceptable according to ASTM C 795 or equivalent testing to verify compatibility and resistance to corrosion.

findings.issue: Fire-rated insulation is specified with placeholder text '[1] [2]-hour fire rating' without indicating which fire rating is required. This is incomplete and will require clarification before submittals are acceptable.
findings.existingText: Fire-Rated Board:  Structural-grade, press-molded, xonolite calcium silicate, fireproofing board suitable for operating temperatures up to 1700 deg F.  Comply with ASTM C 656, Type II, Grade 6.  Tested and certified to provide a [1] [2]-hour fire rating by an NRTL acceptable to authorities having jurisdiction.
findings.replacementText: Fire-Rated Board:  Structural-grade, press-molded, xonolite calcium silicate, fireproofing board suitable for operating temperatures up to 1700 deg F.  Comply with ASTM C 656, Type II, Grade 6.  Tested and certified to provide a 2-hour fire rating by an NRTL acceptable to authorities having jurisdiction.

findings.section: Part 3, EXECUTION - PENETRATIONS - Insulation Installation at Fire-Rated Wall and Partition Penetrations
findings.issue: Section references 'Section 078413 "Penetration Firestopping" twice, but CSI 2020 may have different section numbering (e.g., 078413 vs 078400 range). Verify section number is correct for this project's specification organization.
findings.existingText: Comply with requirements in Section 078413 "Penetration Firestopping"irestopping and fire-resistive joint sealers.
findings.replacementText: Comply with requirements in the Penetration Firestopping section and fire-resistive joint sealer requirements of the Contract Documents.

findings.section: Part 3, EXECUTION - INSTALLATION OF MINERAL-FIBER INSULATION - Blanket Insulation Installation on Ducts and Plenums
findings.issue: Specification allows adhesive coverage to be '100 percent' but then includes a note that 'many manufacturers do not recommend 100 percent coverage.' This contradictory guidance may result in non-compliant installations. The specification should clarify the required coverage percentage.
findings.existingText: Apply adhesives according to manufacturer's recommended coverage rates per unit area, for 100 percent coverage of duct and plenum surfaces.
findings.replacementText: Apply adhesives according to manufacturer's written recommendations for coverage rates per unit area. Verify coverage rate with insulation manufacturer to ensure fire-performance characteristics are maintained.

findings.section: Part 2, PRODUCTS - INSULATION MATERIALS - Flexible Elastomeric Insulation
findings.issue: Specification states elastomeric insulation is unsuitable for temperatures 'lower than minus 70 deg F (minus 57 deg C) and higher than 220 deg F (104 deg C)' but then later product specs reference products with different temperature limits (e.g., Armacell products rated to 220 deg F). Temperature limits should be verified with specific product data.
findings.existingText: "Flexible Elastomeric Insulation" Paragraph below is unsuitable for temperatures lower than minus 70 deg F (minus 57 deg C) and higher than 220 deg F (104 deg C).
findings.replacementText: Flexible Elastomeric Insulation: Verify maximum service temperature with manufacturer's product data. Standard flexible elastomeric is typically unsuitable for temperatures lower than minus 70 deg F (minus 57 deg C) and higher than 220 deg F (104 deg C) unless specifically rated otherwise.

findings.issue: References MIL-A-24179A and MIL-A-3316C standards, but these military specifications are no longer current (MIL-A-3316C last updated October 1987). ASTM equivalents should be specified instead or in addition.
findings.existingText: Flexible Elastomeric and Polyolefin Adhesive:  Comply with MIL-A-24179A, Type II, Class I.
findings.replacementText: Flexible Elastomeric and Polyolefin Adhesive:  Comply with MIL-A-24179A, Type II, Class I, or equivalent ASTM standard with comparable performance characteristics.

findings.issue: Specification states 'Do not weld brackets, clips, or other attachment devices to piping, fittings, and specialties' but does not provide alternative attachment methods for situations where welding may be the only practical option. This could create constructability issues.
findings.existingText: Do not weld brackets, clips, or other attachment devices to piping, fittings, and specialties.
findings.replacementText: Do not weld brackets, clips, or other attachment devices to insulated piping, fittings, and specialties. Use mechanical fasteners, bands, or clamps as specified in Section 230529 unless welding is approved in writing by the Engineer.

findings.issue: Specification requires corrosion coating on stainless steel and carbon steel piping but specifies epoxy coating thicknesses (5 mils each) without citing a standard or source. The requirement for demineralized water on stainless steel is not justified by referenced standards.
findings.existingText:
Surface Preparation:  Clean and prepare surfaces to be insulated.  Before insulating, apply a corrosion coating to insulated surfaces as follows:

Stainless Steel:  Coat 300 series stainless steel with an epoxy primer 5 mils thick and an epoxy finish 5 mils thick if operating in a temperature range between 140 and 300 deg F.  Consult coating manufacturer for appropriate coating materials and application methods for operating temperature range.

Carbon Steel:  Coat carbon steel operating at a service temperature between 32 and 300 deg F with an epoxy coating.  Consult coating manufacturer for appropriate coating materials and application methods for operating temperature range.
findings.replacementText: Surface Preparation:  Clean and prepare surfaces to be insulated.  Before insulating, consult coating and insulation manufacturers regarding need for corrosion coating based on service temperature, humidity, and piping material compatibility. Follow manufacturer's written recommendations.

findings.section: Part 3, EXECUTION - INSTALLATION OF MINERAL-FIBER INSULATION - Insulation Installation on Pipe Flanges
findings.issue: Specification requires mineral-fiber blanket insulation to fill voids between flange insulation and pipe, but blanket is less rigid than preformed board and may not maintain structural integrity at flanges. Guidance should recommend board insulation for this application.
findings.existingText: Fill voids between inner circumference of flange insulation and outer circumference of adjacent straight pipe segments with mineral-fiber blanket insulation.
findings.replacementText: Fill voids between inner circumference of flange insulation and outer circumference of adjacent straight pipe segments with mineral-fiber board insulation of same thickness as pipe insulation or use manufacturer-recommended filler material to maintain structural support.

findings.section: Part 3, EXECUTION - METAL FABRICATIONS - Field Welding
findings.issue: Specification requires compliance with 'AWS D1.1/D1.1M procedures' but lists procedures as semicolons and ampersands in inconsistent format. Minor editing for clarity.
findings.existingText: Field Welding:  Comply with AWS D1.1/D1.1M procedures for shielded, metal arc welding; appearance and quality of welds; and methods used in correcting welding work; and with the following:
findings.replacementText: Field Welding:  Comply with AWS D1.1/D1.1M for shielded metal arc welding, including procedures for appearance and quality of welds and methods for correcting welding work, as follows:

findings.fileName: 230593 - TESTING, ADJUSTING, AND BALANCING FOR HVAC.docx
findings.section: Part 3, EXECUTION - REPORTING - FINAL REPORT - Pump Test Reports
findings.issue: Text states 'Net positive suction head is important for pumps in open circuits...' as a standalone sentence within a structured list. This should be integrated into the pump testing procedures or removed.
findings.existingText:
Net positive suction head is important for pumps in open circuits and for pumps handling fluids at elevated temperatures.

Pump Test Reports:  Calculate impeller size...
findings.replacementText: Pump Test Reports:  Calculate impeller size...

findings.issue: Product list for Fire-Rated Blanket includes '3M; Fire Barrier Wrap Products' without a specific product name. Typically, 3M's product line should be specified more precisely.
findings.existingText: 3M; Fire Barrier Wrap Products.
findings.replacementText: 3M; Fire Barrier Wrap (product line to be specified by manufacturer).

findings.issue: Specification states 'Terminate insulation above roof surface' for indoor-only insulation applications, but does not specify how to seal the termination. This is ambiguous.
findings.existingText: For applications requiring only indoor insulation, terminate insulation above roof surface and seal with joint sealant.
findings.replacementText: For applications requiring only indoor insulation, terminate insulation above roof surface and seal with joint sealant compatible with roof membrane and insulation jacket material.

findings.issue: Comment states 'Knauf is the only mineral-fiber insulation manufacturer that offers factory-applied FSP jacket for blanket insulation.' This is editorial commentary that should not be in a specification. It may also be outdated.
findings.existingText: Knauf is the only mineral-fiber insulation manufacturer that offers factory-applied FSP jacket for blanket insulation.  CertainTeed and Johns Manville offer a vinyl jacket, but it does not comply with ASTM C 1136.  Owens Corning does not offer an FSP or a vinyl product.

findings.section: Part 2, PRODUCTS - TRAPEZE PIPE HANGERS and METAL FRAMING SYSTEMS
findings.issue: The specification includes redundant paragraphs stating 'Trapeze pipe hanger in paragraph below requires calculating and detailing at each use' and 'Metal framing systems in this article require calculating and detailing at each use' multiple times. This repetitive language is unnecessary and clutters the specification.

findings.section: Part 2, PRODUCTS - MASTICS and LAGGING ADHESIVES
findings.issue: Extended commentary about permeance ratings and mastic categories ('The industry does not have a clear definition...') is tutorial language that should not be in a construction specification. This should be removed or moved to specification notes/commentary.

Specification includes detailed commentary about product performance being 'based on products manufactured by Venture Tape' with notation of 'slight variations among manufacturers.' This editorial information should not be in the specification body.
